docs.snippet: Using Google Maps, two friends took a virtual road trip and "drove" from Los Angeles to Richmond, Va., with their mice and keyboards as steering wheels....
docs.lead_paragraph: The other day, my daughter, Sasha, was exploring the Great Barrier Reef off the northeast coast of Australia. She'd flown there by seaplane and was scuba diving 30 feet down when - whoosh! - a giant Maori wrasse, a thick, bluish-yellow fish that looks as if it's made of Plasticene and is twice her size, zipped by. Next, after startling a stingray, she swam around with a bottlenose dolphin, before heading back up to the surface and on to the Serengeti for a hot-air-balloon safari.

headline.main: Virtual Vacations

docs.abstract: Using Google Maps, two friends took a virtual road trip and "drove" from Los Angeles to Richmond, Va., with their mice and keyboards as steering wheels.

docs.snippet: The next generation of radio listeners might not remember the olden days of scrolling through stations by turning a knob on a car or home stereo. Instead, the radio they listen to could very well be on their mobile phones.     Pandora, which runs ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The next generation of radio listeners might not remember the olden days of scrolling through stations by turning a knob on a car or home stereo. Instead, the radio they listen to could very well be on their mobile phones. Pandora, which runs a popular streaming radio Web site, on Wednesday released its application for phones running the Android software from Google. It's available for download in the Android Market. Pandora is available on the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre. Of the 65,000 people who register for a Pandora account each day, 45,000 do so on mobile phones, said Tim Westergren, above, Pandora's founder. ''I'm beginning to think that our future is going to be more mobile-centric than I had even thought, and sooner,'' he said.

headline.main: Dial-Surfing on a Cellphone

docs.abstract: Bits column on cellphone application released by Pandora, which runs popular streaming radio Web site, for phones running Android software from Google; photo (S)

docs.snippet: A not-so quick survey of Google's new Fast Flip....
docs.lead_paragraph: The functional elegance of RSS feeds that bring news to your door like a faithful dog is beyond dispute, but no one is going to argue that it's fun to look at or replicates the offline thrill of flipping a page and finding something completely unexpected. But online reading might have just picked up a few tricks from the offline world. As Miguel Helft has noted, Google made of a bit of a splash on Monday at the TechCrunch50 conference when they unveiled Fast Flip, an experimental news hub that uses pre-loaded static images of news pages so that readers can quickly scan through an a visually inviting database of news.

headline.main: A Not-So-Fast Flip Through Google's Shiny New Toy

docs.abstract: A not-so quick survey of Google's new Fast Flip.

docs.snippet: Acknowledging once again that humans are better than computer algorithms at some tasks, Google said on Wednesday that it had acquired ReCaptcha, a start-up that grew out of a research project at Carnegie Mellon, for an undisclosed amount.     Capt...
docs.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging once again that humans are better than computer algorithms at some tasks, Google said on Wednesday that it had acquired ReCaptcha, a start-up that grew out of a research project at Carnegie Mellon, for an undisclosed amount. Captchas are those strange word puzzles that Web sites use to distinguish humans from automated spamming software and other nasty ''bots.'' ReCaptcha, founded by the inventor of the captcha, the computer scientist Luis von Ahn, puts this test to practical use, taking words from decaying old newspapers and other texts that computers can't read and letting people identify them, thus proving that they are people.

headline.main: Google Buys Digitizing Service

docs.abstract: Bits blog reports Google has acquired digitizing service ReCaptcha for undisclosed amount (S)
